publications.title: When to Forget? Complexity Trade-offs in Machine Unlearning
publications.authors: Martin Van Waerebeke, Marco Lorenzi, Giovanni Neglia, Kevin Scaman
publications.abstract: Can unlearning be done efficiently? Sometimes! We identify three efficiency regimes for first-order unlearning algorithms, analyzing how their speeds compare to retraining depending on the fraction of data to forget, privacy constraints, and allowed errors.

publications.title: SIFU: Sequential Informed Federated Unlearning for efficient and provable client unlearning in federated optimization
publications.authors: Yann Fraboni*, Martin Van Waerebeke*, Kevin Scaman, Richard Vidal, Laetitia Kameni, Marco Lorenzi
publications.venue: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics (AISTATS)
publications.abstract: We propose an algorithm for provable unlearning in federated learning, using differential privacy-based guarantees. The algorithm can deal with non-convex loss functions and has improved performances for convex and strongly convex losses.

publications.title: A primal–dual data-driven method for computational optical imaging with a photonic lantern
publications.authors: C Santos Garcia, M Larchevêque, S O'Sullivan, M Van Waerebeke, Jean-Christophe Pesque and Audrey Repetti.
publications.abstract: Primal-dual approaches can be used to solve inverse imaging problems when there is a known prior. We replace the usual simple priors (i.e. prox on the L1 loss) with denoising neural networks and achieve improved results.

publications.title: On the pitfalls of entropy-based uncertainty for multi-class semi-supervised segmentation
publications.authors: Martin Van Waerebeke, Gregory Lodygensky, Jose Dolz
publications.venue: International Workshop on Uncertainty for Safe Utilization of Machine Learning in Medical Imaging
publications.abstract: Entropy of predictions over several perturbed inferences is a popular uncertainty measure for self-supervised segmentation. We show that is has important flaws in multi-class settings and propose better-performing alternatives.
